docs.text: What is a matrix A matrix is a multidimensional collection of objects. How are matrices stored in memory? As mentioned before, matrices are multidimensional. Since computer memory is one-dimensional, we need to flatten the matrix. This is where strides come into play. A stride is the number of bytes between elements in memory. This is usually equal to the element size. (Unless the matrix is padded) This means that for a matrix \(A\) of size \(m\times{n}\) with a stride of 1, the elements \(A_{i, j}\) and \(A_{i+1, j}\) are 1 byte apart and the elements \(A_{i, j}\) and \(A_{i, j+1}\) are m bytes apart.
